awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2019 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Takumi Murayama is " The minimal model program and moduli theory in positive characteristic". The host institution for the fellowship is Princeton University and the sponsoring scientist is Janos Kollar.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The PI was funded by Grant No. DMS-1902616 during his tenure as a postdoctoral research fellow at Princeton University from September 2019 to August 2022. The project funded the PI's research activities including traveling to conferences, meeting collaborators, and disseminating research in research seminars. During the duration of this project, the PI also supervised undergraduate and graduate research and co-organized a conference and a special session at an AMS sectional meeting.

The research funded by this project is in the fields of algebraic geometry and commutative algebra. Algebraic geometry is the study of algebraic varieties, which are solution sets for systems of polynomial equations. A fundamental tension in this area is that simplifying these systems of polynomial equations in one way may result in complications in other ways. For example, even if one starts with a system of polynomial equations, it is sometimes necessary to work with solutions to equations like y=x2/3. Since this equation is not differentiable at x=0, we say it has a singularity at x=0.

This project aimed to systematically understand how to work with singularities and other issues that arise when trying to simplify systems of polynomial equations. Over the complex numbers, two important tools used in studying polynomial equations are Kodaira-type vanishing theorems and resolutions of singularities. These results are fundamental to our understanding of algebraic geometry over the complex numbers, in particular in birational geometry and the minimal model program.

The PI proved that Kodaira-type vanishing theorems hold for schemes in equal characteristic zero of arbitrary dimension and helped develop techniques to replace Kodaira-type vanishing theorems when they do not hold (in positive or mixed characteristic). The PI applied these techniques to study singularities and their behavior under geometric operations like group quotients, stereographic projections, deformations, and flat morphisms. Understanding singularities and their behavior is especially important when resolutions of singularities are not known to hold. The PI also resolved the last remaining cases of a question of Hochster and Huneke on the behavior of symbolic powers in regular rings using perfectoid techniques (in mixed characteristic) to replace vanishing theorems and resolutions of singularities.


Last Modified: 11/15/2022
Modified by: Takumi Murayama
